newsitem.title: UK: UK's Hamilton confirmed by Conservative Party.
newsitem.headline: UK's Hamilton confirmed by Conservative Party.

text.p: Neil Hamilton, a former Conservative minister accused of taking cash for asking parliamentary questions, was confirmed by local members of the party on Tuesday as their candidate for Britain's May 1 election.
Local Conservative Party Tresurer Tony Martin said Hamilton was adopted by a vote of 182-100 by party members in a meeting at the 500-year-old Dixon Arms pub.
"One hundred and eighty-two people voted to select him as candidate. One hundred did not vote to select him," he told reporters waiting outside the meeting.

Despite pressure from senior Conservative Party officials Hamilton has refused to stand down. He has consistently denied the allegations in the influence-peddling scandal that has hurt the ruling Conservatives who are 20 points behind Labour in national opinion polls.

Hamilton's persistence and a decision by veteran BBC war correspondent Martin Bell to stand against him as an anti-corruption candidate have pushed the sleaze issue and the Tatton seat in northwest England to the forefront of the election campaign.

Prime Minister John Major had refused to get involved, insisting that the decision on who should stand for the seat that Hamilton won in 1992 with a large majority of votes, should be left to the local party.

"It is the responsibility of the people who elect their MP in the Conservative Party to select or deselect a candidate," he said in television interview earlier on Tuesday. "It is the responsibility of the candidate to decide whether or not they will stand.
As Hamilton entered the pub for the meeting he admitted to feeling more like a pop star than a politician when he was mobbed by reporters and cameramen.
"It's just like being Liam Gallagher (lead singer of the pop group Oasis)," Hamilton told reporters.
Asked her feelings about the meeting, Christine Hamilton replied, "Let's face the music and dance."
Bell, when told that Hamilton had been confirmed as the Conservative candidate, said he would fight him to the finish.
Earlier on Tuesday the two men came face-to-face in a confrontation as Bell was about to address an open-air press conference explaining why he was standing in the constituency.
The two, standing inches apart and surrounded by a forest of cameras and microphones, traded verbal thrust and counter-thrust.
Hamilton asked the highly respected journalist if he was trying to destroy his political career.
"The irresistible inference to be drawn from that is that you think I am guilty of corruption in some shape or form," said Hamilton.
Bell, who has dodged bullets for 30 years in wars from Vietnam to Bosnia, answered: "I think the issue of trust is important."
"I have not admitted any mendacity," Hamilton came back.
Bell, wearing his trademark white suit worn as a talisman on battlefields around the world, said he would not be drawn into the debate surrounding the cash for questions affair.
"I refuse to be ambushed like this," he said.
Bell announced his intention to stand on Sunday. He is supported by both main opposition parties, who have withdrawn their candidates.
His intervention is unprecedented in post-war British politics. Bookmakers say he is 2-5 favourite to defeat Hamilton.
